main.commit_message: CI: update to actions/checkout@v3
CI: add Coverity Scanning

Avoid underflowing access to in inbuf

This fixes an out of bounds memory access in some error cases.

Here's a minified base64 encoded testcase:

H52QMDAwMDAwDjAwMDAwMDAwBDAwMDAwMDAwDTAwMDAwMAEwMDAwMBs=

The bug can be triggered by compiling ncompress with asan and passing
above testcase to "compress -dc".

The problem here is that the error message in line 1395 (compress.c)
tries to display one byte left of the affected area, but if p starts 
at position 0 of inbuf this is invalid memory. I'm avoiding this by
increasing p by one if this is the case. (It's debatable whether that's 
the best fix and there are obviously other ways, but it seems simple
enough and fixes the issue.)

drop support for Travis CI

It's shut down, and there's already have x86 GH actions running.  We
lost non-x86 coverage, but so it goes.  I don't think there was ever
breakage on non-x86 systems only.
trim excess whitespace
unify codestyle
fix spelling

constify & localize fast prime lookup table

This moves a large chunk of data out of the writable section and into
the read-only text section.

drop support for explicit byte order

We can read & write the compressed formats easily and let the compiler
deal with the host cpu endianness.  We already have code to do just
that too, so this is deleting largely unused logic.

mark all local functions as static

This saves a small amount of space as the compiler can do better.

require standard C function prototype support

We can drop the main prototype entirely as we don't need it.

drop support for MAXSEG_64K knob

This code path is never tested anymore, and if your system is so
old or small to need this, you can use an old ncompress release.
bump version to 5.1
move changelog entirely to Changes file

fixed nine bits processing, updated reset code behaviour

Closes #5.

The problem is that extcode and maxcode together with n_bits were not properly
 initialized and reset. I've added code in the same style as code around.
release 5.0

go back to setmode define

Apparently macOS has a non-standard setmode() func in its unistd.h
that conflicts with this fallback, so go back to using a define, but
don't bother having it "return" a value since we aren't (currently)
checking it.
use io.h fallbacks on mingw too

build: switch from sed to awk for macOS

The sed on macOS doesn't like this script, so use simpler tools.

add a standard -k (keep) option

Many compressors have a keep option to not delete their inputs.

clean up help text a bit

Add missing info about -- and change "file" to "path" to avoid
confusion when specifying a directory.
build: make sure Changes & patchlevel.h stay in sync

tweak setmode fallback to avoid warnings

GCC doesn't like literal 0's as statements.

move Windows CI from Travis to GH actions

This uses clang to build rather than MS tools.  This should still
provide good Windows coverage, so we can figure that out later.
added setmode binary for stdin and stdout on windows
Adding ppc64le architecture support on travis-ci

disable "deprecated" API warnings on Windows

The MSVC env has deprecated a lot of standard POSIX functions like
open() and want people to use Windows-specific APIs instead because
they're more "secure".  That isn't going to happen, so disable the
deprecation warnings instead.

include io.h on Windows

Hopefully this should provide the basic open/close/read/write APIs.
add missing return type to access fallback

fix Windows access fallback logic

The standard access API returns 0/-1 on pass/fail, so the replacement
should do the same.  Checking the stat return value and returning a
bool incorrectly inverts the logic.

Fixes #28.

CI: move macOS & Linux+amd64 to GH actions

Can't move all of Travis targets as GH actions doesn't easily support
non-x86 architectures.  Need to figure out how Windows works under GH
actions before migrating that.
README: rename master->main branch

drop support for dead operating systems

No one runs PDP11/VAX systems anymore.  If they did, they probably
aren't building this latest version, so they can stick to ancient
releases instead.

drop support for explicit unaligned memory accesses

It's unlikely anyone defined this anymore, so we'll rely on the
compiler for performance here.  If need be, we can look at some
helpers like memcpy or byteswap.

drop support for REGISTER build knob

Leave it to the compiler to do register allocation rather than
manually managing register keywords on local variables.  Modern
compilers should be more than capable in getting decent perf
without all this effort.  Plus, we have no code/tests to check
this behavior easily which means no one does it.

drop DIRENT/SYSDIR config knobs

Since dirent.h is required by POSIX 2001, there's no need to support
sys/dir.h or to offer a config setting to users.  Assume it exists
everywhere (except DOS/WINDOWS for now).

drop old DEF_ERRNO support

Since errno.h & errno are required by POSIX 2001, there's no need
for this DEF_ERRNO symbol anymore.  Punt it.

travis: update build matrix

Only test clang on macOS & Windows as those are the primary compilers
on those platforms.  Shouldn't need GCC coverage anymore there.

Add more arches for Linux targets, and drop the obsolete sudo setting.

compress: improve & fix recursive mode

The 4.2 version broke the exit status when running in recursive
mode and some files were skipped due to already being compressed
or decompressed.  While we fix that, also address the UI that the
4.1 version (which added recursive mode) documented: we simply do
not warn if files are already compressed/decompressed.
tests: add debug output on failures
README: switch travis branch to master

compress: drop support for 2.0 output & -C option #26

The -C option for producing compress-2.0 compatible files has
been broken since the first ncompress-4.2 release in 1992.  It
seems like no one has really noticed, and even recently, it was
only by someone developing tests.

Since compress-3.0 was released in 1985, there shouldn't be a
need to support producing files that compress-2.0 can accept.

We still accept the output of compress-2.0 and older, we just
no longer support producing files only those ancient versions
will accept.

Closes #26.

kick off new 5.x version series

The compress releases have had a tumultuous history.  The last official
version was 4.0 in Aug 1985.  All releases since have been intermittent
and completely unofficial.  In fact, ncompress itself is an unofficial
follow up to the unofficial 4.1 patches by Dave Mack.

The 4.2.4.x fork by myself was to make it clear that it was a follow up
to Peter's 4.2.4 release as I didn't have any history/context.  In case
Peter did another release, I didn't have to have any conflicts or there
to be confusion as to what's newer (he'd just release 4.2.5 or 4.3).

After quite a lot of digging, it's clear Peter's 4.2.x series was both
itself an unofficial update to compress, and a one-off from 1992.  As
my fork has been around long enough at this point (~15 years), and the
wider community have opted to switch to mine over anything else (*),
update the version series to reflect this by moving to 5.0.  No one
else is maintaining compress or ncompress projects, and the original
authors aren't around to bless any forks.

It's better to keep the ncompress name rather than reverting to the
old "compress" if only for clarity when searching Google.  Attempting
to search for "compress" will result in a ton of noise that cannot be
reasonably filtered out.  On the other hand, searching for "ncompress"
only finds relevant results :).

(*) Most BSD's have their own independent forks that date back to the
last official compress-4.0 release.  Since they maintain a single code
base with `compress` in it, it's unlikely they'd use any external code
regardless of licensing.

compress.c: rename back from compress42.c

This had been renamed by Peter to avoid confusion with other people
making their own releases of compress with version 4.2.  It's been
long enough at this point that we can rename back as those other
release streams have died, and no one distributes sources via cpios
on usenet anymore.

MANIFEST: drop unused file

This serves no useful purpose anymore.  Punt it.

build: drop use of $version

It's only used to display the string to the user as an FYI.
Drop it from the script to simplify and to avoid having to
keep the version in sync with the actual code (especially as
it has been out of date for a long time at this point).
start 4.2.4.7 development
release 4.2.4.6

Changes: use * for lists

This makes markdown integration easier.
Makefile.def: run spellcheck over it

make: improve Makefile generation

Set & export default CFLAGS in the GNUmakefile so we get sane behavior
by default.  We can't rely on POSIX make for this unfortunately.

Stop manually inserting CFLAGS & LDFLAGS when creating the Makefile as
Makefile.def already uses both of them.

do not set exit_code when an error is ignored

Resolves: #22

set the mandir to use $(PREFIX)/share/man by default

/usr/man doesn't really exist anywhere I can see, and /usr/local/man is
deprecated in favor of matching /usr

don't strip binaries by default, users might want unstripped versions

And most packaging automation methods will already have mechanisms to do
this by default for installed binaries, and/or allow this to be
overridden or produce split debug symbols.

make: add PREFIX conformance, add option to only install main program

Inspired by similar logic from the master branch. This makes the install
routine useful for linux packaging without a lot of post-install
cleanup.
travis: add support for Windows

add xxx->_xxx redirects on WINDOWS

The Windows headers deprecate a bunch of POSIX functions and want
people to use the _ prefixed version instead.  Because why not.
disable chmod/chown/utime for mingw builds too
disable unistd.h include on DOS & WINDOWS
add a fallback for access() for DOS & WINDOWS

disable utime usage on AMIGA/DOS/WINDOWS #18

This doesn't seem to be available there.

move LSTAT check to a symbol redefine to simplify

This way we don't have to check LSTAT/lstat/stat every time.

add a WINDOWS define for disabling chmod/chown #18

This covers native Windows builds/toolchains.  This isn't for mingw.

add chmod/chown stubs for AMIGA/DOS #18

This way we don't have to keep ifdefs inline in the body of the code.
drop old unused MARK & SIZE_INNER_LOOP defines

drop support for NOFUNCDEF

Probably aren't any systems left where we can't rely on their headers
defining these functions properly.

tests: fix typo #12

Forgot to remove forced typo after testing.

tests: fallback to python for readlink for macOS #19

Closes #19.
start 4.2.4.6 development
release 4.2.4.5
man: add a uncompress(1) link to compress(1)
add support for -- to halt option parsing
tests: fallback to readlink if realpath is missing

start a testsuite

Pretty basic stuff, but it's better than nothing.

change version output to go to stdout

When people request version output, send it to stdout since they
asked for it rather than stderr like a failure.

add a standard -h (help) option

We have to tweak the exit status & output handling so help writes to
stdout and exits 0 like a normal option.

replace fixed stack size with filenames with dynamic buffers

This avoids the 1k path limit that MAXPATHLEN imposes.  Now we let the
OS throw an error if the paths are too long rather than always assuming
no path will be 1k+ bytes long.

It does mean we're allocating more heap memory than we were before, but
it shouldn't matter on any system built in the last two decades.

replace fixed stack size in recursive dir handler with dynamic buffers

This avoids the 1k path limit that MAXPATHLEN imposes.  Now we let the
OS throw an error if the paths are too long rather than always assuming
no path will be 1k+ bytes long.

simplify & constify the argument to comprexx

This makes it clear the code doesn't modify the buffer when running.
rebuild Makefile when GNUmakefile changes
define LSTAT=1 in modern builds

fix -Werror=parentheses errors with newer compilers

Add parens around the inline assignments in the control code to tell
the compiler the assignment is intentional.

change signal ifdef logic to the signal names #18

Rather than worry about specific OS differences (and expanding the
existing DOS-vs-Windows logic), change the signal ifdefs to look
for the signal names instead.

drop old long filename checks #12

This logic makes sense on old DOS/Windows systems which have 8.3
filename limitations, but those haven't been relevant in over a
decade.  Lets drop the logic to simplify.

If anyone on such an old system still wants to work with compress
files, they can just use shorter names, or get a build from the
FreeDOS project.

Closes #12.

don't leak file descriptor in error cases

This was wasting fd numbers if ncompress operated recursively.

Fix integer overflow in maxmaxcode computation

If maxbits is 31, then computing maxmaxcode causes signed integer
overflow, which is undefined behavior.

To fix this, check for overlarge maxbits before computing maxmaxcode.
Fix typo
README: link in travis status
enable travis CI

drop use of datestamp in compiled output

This doesn't add that much (if any) value to the version output, and it
prevents systems from caching the results or reproducing it later on.
Drop it all.

Fixes #3.

use intmax_t to print nlink_t fields

Since nlink_t can be int or long or bigger depending on the ABI/platform,
use intmax_t from stdint.h instead to print the value.
add note wrt patents (they all expired)
add explicit licensing details

migrate to github

Signed-off-by: Mike Frysinger <vapier@gmail.com>

fix typo in version output

Reported-by: Ulrich Müller <ulm@gentoo.org>
Signed-off-by: Mike Frysinger <vapier@gmail.com>
